summary: This is a reply letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorney to Judge Alison J. Nathan, filed under seal, in support of a request to modify a protective order. The letter argues that Maxwell should be allowed to inform the Second Circuit Court of Appeals and a district court judge in a related civil case that her civil adversary has already provided nearly 90,000 pages of sealed civil discovery materials to the U.S. Attorney's Office via subpoena, and that these materials now constitute over half of the criminal discovery against her. The defense contests the government's claims that the civil case is unrelated and that its subpoena practice was standard.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The criminal defendant seeking to modify a protective order to disclose to other courts that her civil adversary has provided sealed civil discovery materials to the prosecution.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, to whom this sealed reply letter is addressed.

persons.name: Jeffrey Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C., who authored and signed this reply letter on behalf of Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Judge Preska
persons.context: A district court judge presiding over the related civil litigation and the unsealing process for materials in that case.

persons.name: Judge McMahon
persons.context: A judge before whom the government made similar 'standard practice' arguments regarding subpoenas for civil materials.

persons.name: Judge Koeltl
persons.context: Cited for a prior observation that the government may not use its investigative powers to modify a protective order merely to compare civil discovery with a criminal investigation.

persons.name: Judge Sweet
persons.context: The judge who originally approved the civil protective order that Maxwell relied upon.

connections.description: Pagliuca is Maxwell's defense attorney, authoring this legal filing on her behalf.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case; Maxwell is petitioning the court via this filing.
Judge Preska is presiding over the related civil litigation where unsealing of materials is being considered; Maxwell seeks to inform her of the government's possession of those materials.

events.title: Maxwell's Request to Modify Protective Order
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell filed a request to modify the protective order in her criminal case.

events.title: Maxwell's Brief Filed in Second Circuit
events.description: Maxwell filed an opening brief in the Second Circuit Court of Appeals arguing for maintaining her first deposition under seal.

events.title: Filing of Sealed Reply Letter
events.description: Maxwell's defense files this sealed reply letter in support of the motion to modify the protective order.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's civil litigation adversary provided nearly 90,000 pages of materials under a protective order to the U.S. Attorney's Office via subpoena.
These 90,000 pages of civil discovery now constitute more than half of the total 165,000 pages of criminal discovery provided to Maxwell's defense.
The defense argues the civil and criminal cases are directly related, as the indictment quotes from the sealed civil materials.
Maxwell seeks only to disclose, under seal to the judges overseeing the civil unsealing process, the fact that the government already possesses these materials.
The defense contests the government's claim that its ex parte subpoena for the civil materials was 'standard practice,' citing contrary Second Circuit precedent.
